What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:

Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: This course taught me how to think and work in a laboratory setting. I learned how to collaborate with lab groups and also solve problems that arise with scientific research.
This course developed my ability to do rigorous and effective research, organize my data and conclusions into a good format, and present it in a way which is engaging and thoughtful.
I learned the process behind both executing original scientific research and writing up those results into a paper.
I learned how to conduct a research project and write a scientific paper at the end, which was no small feat.

I learned how to analysis data and draw inferences from it as well as learning how to look through sources to build a good background. I also  become more familiar with how to write a scientific paper and prepare a poster.
Improve use of scientific method.
I performed actual lab research for the first time. It was extremely fruitful and exciting. I had guidance and also a lot of independence.
I got a sense of what lab work and research actually entails, plus I am now more experienced at navigating the literature, running analyses, and presenting my findings.

Time management for independent research
Data analysis and programming
How micro-level observation and study can allow us to approach fundamental questions of ecology and evolution. For instance, fish phylogenetics allows investigation of larger questions of the process of speciation and genetic divergence.

This course was great at teaching the student to be an independent researcher. I think the course could be improved by having a bit clearer guidelines on the expectations of the student throughout the semester.
Its entireky self-motivated, which is a strength for some and a weakness for others.

I had a great experience with my advisor, but I would have appreciated more guidance and even suggested deadlines from the major, as I know some other majors provide. For example, a recommended date for a draft would have been helpful.

A colloquium to meet with other E&EB seniors working on independent research for a small amount of time once a week would have been nice. Getting feedback from other students and problem solving as a group would have been a good experience, rather than just going to our PI's with all of our problems we could have learned together.
Strengths include close cooperation with my advisor and a very detailed and easy to follow set of instructions for writing the paper and creating the poster.
It was a fantastic experience!

Strengths - extremely educational in a practical sense, rewarding at the end of the day

Weaknesses - the symposium had several drawbacks. We were expected to be there for 7-8 hours which is ridiculous during reading week. The presentations, while generally good, did not seem to be chosen in a completely fair way. For example, having two presentations about the same organism or ecosystem shuts out people with completely different areas of research. May have been worth asking advisors for projects they thought were done really well, or even having a small informal application process like a 1 paragraph email explaining why your topic would be worth presenting.
Yes. Both because it is required but also because it represents an invaluable opportunity.
Yes, if you do a project you are interested.
Yes, considerable room for growth and scientific discovery.
Definitely worth doing the full year.
